q1.value: Examining effects of prototypicality on the selection of the auxiliars "haben" and "sein" in German using a sentence maze paradigm

q3.value:
The selection of "haben" and "sein" is driven by three factors: transitivity, telicity and motion verb semantics influence the selection (Gillmann 2016). First of all, different degrees of transitivity influence which auxiliar is selected: Prototypical transitive sentences select "haben". Prototypical intransitive sentences select "sein" if the sentence is telic or contains a motion verb. Between the prototypes of intransitivity and transitivity, variation is possible, e.g., if the object is ambiguous between patient and instrument (e.g., Ich bin/habe vor 20 Jahren ein schwarzes Pferd geritten ‘I used to ride a black horse twenty years ago’). The influence of transitivity, telicity and motion verb semantics has been studied in corpora, e.g., by Gillmann (2016). Roehm et al. (2013) studied the influence of telicity on the auxiliar selection with respect to degree achievements (e.g. rosten, ‘to rust’) in an EEG study. However, to my knowledge, a psycholinguistic study examining the influence of transitivity on the auxiliar selection in German has not been carried out so far. 
This study examines the influence of transitivity with the help of a sentence maze task. By studying the influence of transitivity, prototypicality effects should be visible, as the influence of transitivity seems to be organised between two prototypes (transitive vs. intransitive sentences) (Gillmann 2016: 302-305). Within a sentence maze task, participants are asked to build a sentence bit by bit. For each chunk of a sentence, participants choose between two options. Within the task, the verbs "fahren" 'to drive', "reiten" 'to ride' and "fliegen" 'to fly' are used in sentences with different degrees of transitivity: transitive (object is used as a patient), ambiguous I (object is ambiguous between patient and instrument), ambiguous II (sentence element is ambiguous between object and adverbial) and intransitive (no object). The participants have to choose between "haben" and "sein" as auxiliar for the main verbs (e.g., gefahren haben/sein). The test sentences are subordinate clauses so that the auxiliar is at the end of each sentence.

q4.value:
1. reaction times

Reaction times are low for prototypical intransitivity. For prototypical intransitivity, they are higher because the sentence is more complex than the intransitive sentence that does not contain an object. It is expected that ambigII elicits similar reaction times as transitive sentences. In contrast, ambigI is expected to elicit the highest reactions times. This hypotheses are based on the results of the prestudy (see data_prestudy_prototypicality.csv for the data and prestudy_prototypicality.R for the code analysing the data statistically). 
Before analysing the data of the prestudy, a different pattern was expected: Reaction times were expected to be low for prototypical transitivity and prototypical intransitivity. For sentences in the periphery (ambiguous I and II), reaction times were expected to be high as both forms are theoretically possible (see https://osf.io/p5myx for the preregistration of the prestudy). 

If the pattern of the prestudy is also visible in the main study, ambiguousII does not seem to be perceived as ambiguous (see also response behaviour) as the comparable reaction times to transitive sentences demonstrate. The reaction times elicited by transitive and ambiguousII sentences being higher than the reaction times elicited by intransitive sentences could be due to the higher complexity of these sentences compared to the intransitive test sentences. The increased reaction times of ambiguousI could be an indicator for variants:  The choice between an entrenched form and a form that is unlikely to be produced should be carried out fast whereas the choice between variants takes longer as two forms with equal function exist.

2. preference in response behaviour

The choice between "haben" and "sein" depends on the transitivity of the sentences: In transitive sentences, only "haben" is possible. "Sein" is used in intransitive sentences if the verb is telic or refers to a motion. As the test verbs within the study are motion verbs, only "sein" should be chosen in the intransitive sentences. The opposite is expected for transitive sentences. Hence, no variation in response behaviour is expected for the prototypical transitive and intransitive sentences. The same is expected for ambiguousII based on the prestudy. For ambiguousI, variation in reponse behaviour is hypothesised. Based on the prestudy, a preference for "sein" over "haben" is expected with respect to ambiguousI. Originally, it was hypothesised that sentences in the periphery between the prototypes would show variation in response behaviour. For ambiguousI, a  preference for "haben" was expected, for ambiguousII a preference for "sein". 

In the preregistration of the prestudy, it was also expected that participants might show a different response behaviour depending on the test verbs for the ambiguous-constructions, e.g. "sein" might be preferred for "reiten" 'to ride' in the ambiguous-I-condition, but "haben" for "fahren" 'to drive' in the same condition. This could be observed for "reiten" in the prestudy. As "reiten" not only elicited a different response behavior but also differing reaction times from the other test items, "reiten" will not be included into the confirmatory analysis, but only into the exploratory analysis (see Analysis Plan).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
A within subject design is used with two factors (transitivity and inflection) with four (transitive, ambiguous I, ambiguous II, intransitive) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Within the levels of transitivity, three test words are used. Only two will be used in the confirmatory analysis, see statistical models. All three test words will be used in the exploratory analysis. The participants can choose between the auxiliaries "hat" and "ist" for each test word. The answer (hat/ist) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
Nouns belonging to the so-called weak declension class in German are used within filler sentences. Here, participants have to choose between weak and strong genitive endings. These items are used as test items in a study on the influence of schemata on variation. Additionally, filler sentences with similar content as the test sentences are used. The whole study design distracts participants form the research interest, as participants always have to choose between two forms. Within the study, participants have to detect grammatical, semantic and orthographic deviations. 
To test the design, forms containing errors in gender marking (der.Mask Kurier.Mask 'courier'/*die.Fem Lieferant.Mask 'delivery man') and in orthography (Schule/*Schuhle ‘school’) are included into the study as well as variants (Fahrrad fahren/fahrradfahren ‘to ride a bike’; fehlerlos/fehlerfrei ‘without mistakes’). For the two errors, a fast and clearly distributed response behaviour is expected. For the two variants, slow reaction times and an inconsistent response behaviour are hypothesised. Hence, the items allow to test, whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The design will only be tested if the test items show no differences in reaction times. 

If the design needs to be tested, the following mixed linear model will be used: RT ~ Variante + (1+Variante|participant)+(1|item). Variante is the manipulated variable that contains two levels: Variante (fehlerlos/fehlerfrei; Fahrradfahren, Fahrrad fahren) and kVariante (Schule/*Schuhle; der Kurier/*die Lieferant). For the response behaviour, a generalized mixed linear model will be used: preferred form ~ Variante + (1+Variante|participant)+(1|item).

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5, (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study. 

Test items
The verbs "fahren" ‘to drive’, "reiten" ‘to ride’ and "fliegen" ‘to fly’ are used as test items as they can be used with different degrees of transitivity. They are used in the following sentences:

Transitive (object that is used as patient)

Er sah, wie die Mutter die Kinder zur Schule gefahren hat/*ist.
He saw that the mother drove the children to the school.

Ich nehme an, dass der Pilot die Passagiere zum nächstgelegenen Flughafen geflogen hat/*ist.
I guess that the pilot flew the passengers to the closest airport.

Ich gehe davon aus, dass das Mädchen das Pferd zur Koppel geritten hat/*ist.
I guess that the girl rode the horse to the paddock.

Ambiguous I (object ambiguous between patient and instrument)

Er erzählte mir, dass seine Tante eine Zeit lang ein Cabrio gefahren hat/ist.
He told me that his aunt drove a convertible for some time.

Ich kann kaum glauben, dass meine Schwester neulich einen Helikopter geflogen hat/ist.
I cannot believe that my sister flew a helicopter the other day.

Mir wurde erzählt, dass mein Onkel früher ein schwarzes Pferd geritten hat/ist.
I was told that my uncle rode a black horse in the past.

Ambiguous II (ambiguous between object and adverbial)

In den Nachrichten sagten sie, dass der neue Fahrer die Strecke in Rekordzeit gefahren ist/hat.
They said in the news that the new driver drove the circuit in record time.

In der Zeitung stand, dass der Pilot die Distanz in Bestzeit geflogen ist/hat.
I read in the newspapers that the pilot flew the distance in minimum time.

Im Radio hieß es, dass der Reiter den Parcours fehlerlos geritten ist/hat.
They said in the radio that the jockey rode the course without any mistakes.

Intransitive (no object)

Ich ging davon aus, dass die Oma am Sonntag zur Kur gefahren ist/*hat.
I thought that grandmother drove to the clinic on Sunday.

Ich wusste nicht, dass mein Bruder am Mittwoch in die USA geflogen ist/*hat.
I did not know that my brother flew to the US on Wednesday.

Meine Oma erzählte, dass sie in den Siebzigern regelmäßig durch den Schwarzwald geritten ist/*hat.
My grandmother told me that she was frequently horseback riding through the black forest in the seventies.

The test sentences were tested for their semantic plausibility. Except for one sentence, all test sentences were rated plausible (at least 3 on a scale from 1 (not plausible) to 5 (plausible), see the attached file (test sentences.csv) for details). Only the test sentence "Mir wurde erzählt, dass mein Onkel früher ein schwarzes Pferd geritten hat" had to be changed slightly. Originally, "während des Studiums" ('during his studies‘) was used instead of "früher" (‘in the past’). As the rated plausibility of this sentence was rather low (2,7), "während des Studiums" was changed to "früher" so that the test sentence is more similar to the other test sentences containing "reiten" as test verb. Another slight change had to be made in the sentence containing "Parcours" ('course'): within the semantic pausibility test, the form "Parkour" was used which is normally not used in the context of horse back riding.

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over the stimuli and the filler items. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: 
unique coding for each stimulus 	

Verwendung: 
coding for the test auxiliaries, levels: trans,ambigI,ambigII, intrans
coding for the items testing the design, levels: nVariante (no variant), Variante (variant)
coding for the test nouns, levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach (not relevant for this study)

Item: 
naming the test items in their base form (main verbs; masculine nouns (not relevant for this study))

Evaluation: 
"ev" in the column highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the items have been answered wrong, the participant will be excluded)	

akzeptierteForm: 
stating which of the forms is expected to be accepted (only for test items), levels: ist/hat/both; n/s/both (not relevant for this study)

Element_richtig: stating the correct element 

Element_Alternative: stating the alternative

Block: block in which the item is presented	

PositionimBlock: position within the block

ElementA: stating ElementA (presented at the left)

ElementA_präf: stating whether ElementA is preferred over ElementB; levels: j (yes), n (no)

ElementB: stating ElementB (presented at the right)

ElementB_präf: stating whether ElementB is preferred over ElementA;  levels: j (yes), n (no)

correctKey: correct response key (based on ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf); levels: f (Element A preferred); j (Element B preferred)

Further explanation for "correctKey": For items which are considered variants, "correctKey" was not specified. For these items, ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf are both coded with j. Note that some filler items (like "dass/das"; "seid/seit") are not variants but are often confused so that both forms were coded as acceptable.

Further explanation to "Element_richtig" and "Element_Alternative": These columns are not used for the analysis of the data. Their only purpose is to help the user spot the correct and alternative forms in the design more easily. For items that are considered variants, Element_richtig and Element_Alternative are also stated.  The variants were assigned randomly to Element_richtig and Element_Alterantive, as both forms are equally likely. They are only used in these columns so that the test sentences can be read completely. In the columns relevant for analysis (ElementA_präf/ElementB_präf, correctKey), these items are coded as variants (ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf are coded with j; correctKey is not specified).

q9.value: The test items are organised in four blocks. In each block, three test sentences are used that have different degrees of transitivity. Per block, each test verb is only included once. Additionally, three filler sentences are included into each block. Test and filler sentences alternate. The order of the sentences within a block does not vary. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students.  If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. In order to avoid regional variation influencing the data, the study will not be distributed in the counties Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg, Rhineland Palatinate and Saarland. In this counties, position verbs are used with "sein" instead of "haben" (Scherr 2019).  This could have an effect on the reaction times and the response behaviour with respect to the test verbs. Participants who indicate one of the stated counties as the county they grew up in will be excluded from the sample.
The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1, indicate that they grew up in a county stated above or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task.This evaluation will be based on 132 filler items. For these items, people should not vary in their answers. The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer 13 items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category transitivity (e.g., intransitive/ambiguousI) are excluded from the sample.

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/maze.

q13.value:
A sample size of 50 participants is targeted. To reach this number, 170 participants will be recruited. In the prestudy, 6 of 32 participants (19  %) had to be excluded due to missing meta data, response behaviour indicating a lack of concentration and reaction times above 3 sd of the mean reaction times for the level of a category (e.g., transitive).  However, participants were not excluded from counties in which "sein" is selected for position verbs. Hence, more data are collected in order to ensure that the targeted sample size of 50 is reached. The targeted 170 participants are also due to a study on schemata and frequency influencing the processing of masculine nouns belonging to the so called weak declension. The test items for the study on schemata and frequency are used as fillers in this study. For the study on schemata and frequency, 125 participants are needed, so that a total sample of 170 participants needs to be collected. See https://osf.io/bhxpz for the preregistration of the study on schemata and frequency.

See https://osf.io/p5myx for the preregistration of the prestudy on prototypicality. Deviating from the preregistration of the prestudy, participants were exluded if 10 % of the items evaluating the concentration of the participants were answered incorrectly. Additionally, participants were excluded whose reaction times were 3 sd above the mean reaction times of a level of the category transitivity (e.g., transitive, ambiguousI).

q14.value:
The sample size is set to 50 participants based on a power analysis for the reaction times: 50 participants are required to reach a power of over 0.87 with an alpha level of 0.01 for the estimates -0.2 for the level "transitive", -0.4 for the level "intransitive" and -0.2 for the level "ambiguousII" of the category "transitivity" in comparions to the level "ambiguousI". The estimates are based on a mixed linear model analysing the data of the prestudy. The  data of the prestudy (data_prestudy_prototypicality.csv) as well as the code analysing the data (prestudy_prototypicality.R) are attached. See https://osf.io/p5myx for the preregistered analysis plan of the prestudy. The code for the data simulation (power analysis_prototypicality.R) calculating the power based on the estimates of the prestudy is attached as well.  The simulation was repeated 10000 times, a file with 10000 repitions of the simulation is attached (sims_prototypicality.csv). See the section "statistical models" for the attached files. The code for the data simulation is based on a tutorial for power analyses with R by DeBruine and Barr (preprint).
Note that the power analysis is based on a model that only uses random intercepts, as the model had convergence issues when random slopes were used. For the main study, random slopes for participants will be included into the modell (see analysis plan).

question.value: The transitivity of the sentences is manipulated in which the test words are used. This categorial variable consists of four levels: transitive, ambiguousI, ambiguousII and intransitive (see study design for an explanation of the levels). Additionally, the auxiliar is manipulated. The levels of this nominal variable are "hat" and "ist".

The outcome variables will be the response behaviour (hat/ist) as well as reaction times to sentences with different degrees of transitivity (see manipulated variables). This is measured by letting the participants choose between the auxiliar "hat" and "ist" at the end of the sentence. The participants are asked to choose the option that fits best to the parts of the sentence that they have read so far. ("Wählen Sie die Möglichkeit, die für Sie am besten zu dem bisher gelesenen Satz passt." 'Choose the option that fits best into the parts of the sentence that you have read so far').  Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 

Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data is used to exclude participants from the study (see data collection procedures) and not included into the confirmatory analysis.

For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019, RStudio Team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.
For the confirmatiory analysis, only "fahren" and "fliegen" will be included into the model. "reiten" elicited a  different response behaviour and different reaction time patterns in the prestudy (see the data (data_prestudy_prototypicality.csv) and the code (prestudy_prototypicality.R) analysing the data of the prestudy). Because of this, "reiten" will only be included into the exploratory analysis.

Reaction times

To evaluate the influence of transitivity on reaction times, a mixed linear model will be conducted. The degree of transitivity (transitive, ambiguous I, ambiguous II, intransitive) is included as fixed effect. Test items and participants are included as random effects. The independent variable is transitivity. The reaction times are the dependent variable.

RT~transitivity +(1+transitivy|item)+(1+transitivy|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes are dropped and only random intercepts are included into the model.

Preference for "haben" or "sein"

To evaluate differences in the preference for "haben" and "sein", a logistic mixed linear model is used. Transitivity (transitive, ambiguous I, ambiguous II, intransitive) is included as fixed effect. Test items and participants are included as random effects. The independent variable is transitivity. The preference for "haben" or "sein" is the dependent variable.

Preference ~ transitivity + (1+transitivity|item)+(1+transitivity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes are dropped and only random intercepts are included into the model.

In the prestudy, convergence issues were reported for the statistical model so that the random effects had to be dropped completely (see prestudy_prototypicality.R). Therefore, a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest was calculated additionally. This will also be carried out in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, transitivity will be included as factor:

Auxiliar ~ Transitivy 

For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_prototypicality.R.

q20.value: If the model for analysing the reaction times does not meet the condition of homoscedasticity and normal distribution of residuals, the reaction times will be transformed into log-reaction times.

q21.value: The alphal-evel is set to .01. Based on the estimates for reaction times of the prestudy, an R2m of  .07and an R2c of .29  is expected.

q22.value: As explained in the data collection procedures, participants will be excluded that do not speak German as their L1, are bilingual, lived in Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg,  Rhineland Palatinate or Saarland before their 12th year of life or have dyslexia. Additionally, the response bevaviour of the participants will be evaluated and data exclusion will be based on this evaluation. In addition, participants whose reaction time is over 3 sd above the mean of reaction times for a level of the category prototypicality (e.g. transitive), will be excluded.

q23.value: Incomplete data sets of participants will not be included into the study. If meta data (except for  the indication of L1, indication of places where participants lived until the 12th year of life and the indication of dyslexia) is missing, particpiants will still be included into the study.

q24.value:
The exploratory analysis will include "reiten" which is excluded from the confirmatory analysis. The same models will be tested that have been described in "statistical models". 

Additionally to these models, a model is used including "item" as fixed effect in order to measure the influence of the test items on reaction times (see prestudy_prototypicality.R for the code). Item and transitivity will be fixed effects in the model that may interact. Participants are included as random effect. 

RT ~ transitivity*item + (1+transitivity|participant)

For the generalized mixed linear model on response behaviour, random effects had to be dropped completely in the prestudy (see prestudy_prototypicality.R) not only for analysing "fahren" and "fliegen" but also when analysing all items. Hence, a conditional inference tree and a random forest were calculated additionally for the response behaviour including all items. The same method will be used for the main study if necessary.

Within the tree and the forest, transitivity as well as the test item will be included as factors:

Auxiliar ~ Transitivy + Item

Item is included because the data of the prestudy indicates that "reiten" elicits different response patterns than the other verbs. The code for the prestudy also includes a tree without item as factor. For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_prototypicality.R.

The described models are included into the exploratory analysis and not into the confirmatory analysis because the interaction of item and transitivity is not the main interest of the study, but the influence of transitivity (and hence prototypicality) on reaction times and on the response behaviour.

registration_responses.q9: The test items are organised in four blocks. In each block, three test sentences are used that have different degrees of transitivity. Per block, each test verb is only included once. Additionally, three filler sentences are included into each block. Test and filler sentences alternate. The order of the sentences within a block does not vary. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
A sample size of 50 participants is targeted. To reach this number, 170 participants will be recruited. In the prestudy, 6 of 32 participants (19  %) had to be excluded due to missing meta data, response behaviour indicating a lack of concentration and reaction times above 3 sd of the mean reaction times for the level of a category (e.g., transitive).  However, participants were not excluded from counties in which "sein" is selected for position verbs. Hence, more data are collected in order to ensure that the targeted sample size of 50 is reached. The targeted 170 participants are also due to a study on schemata and frequency influencing the processing of masculine nouns belonging to the so called weak declension. The test items for the study on schemata and frequency are used as fillers in this study. For the study on schemata and frequency, 125 participants are needed, so that a total sample of 170 participants needs to be collected. See https://osf.io/bhxpz for the preregistration of the study on schemata and frequency.

See https://osf.io/p5myx for the preregistration of the prestudy on prototypicality. Deviating from the preregistration of the prestudy, participants were exluded if 10 % of the items evaluating the concentration of the participants were answered incorrectly. Additionally, participants were excluded whose reaction times were 3 sd above the mean reaction times of a level of the category transitivity (e.g., transitive, ambiguousI).
registration_responses.q14:
The sample size is set to 50 participants based on a power analysis for the reaction times: 50 participants are required to reach a power of over 0.87 with an alpha level of 0.01 for the estimates -0.2 for the level "transitive", -0.4 for the level "intransitive" and -0.2 for the level "ambiguousII" of the category "transitivity" in comparions to the level "ambiguousI". The estimates are based on a mixed linear model analysing the data of the prestudy. The  data of the prestudy (data_prestudy_prototypicality.csv) as well as the code analysing the data (prestudy_prototypicality.R) are attached. See https://osf.io/p5myx for the preregistered analysis plan of the prestudy. The code for the data simulation (power analysis_prototypicality.R) calculating the power based on the estimates of the prestudy is attached as well.  The simulation was repeated 10000 times, a file with 10000 repitions of the simulation is attached (sims_prototypicality.csv). See the section "statistical models" for the attached files. The code for the data simulation is based on a tutorial for power analyses with R by DeBruine and Barr (preprint).
Note that the power analysis is based on a model that only uses random intercepts, as the model had convergence issues when random slopes were used. For the main study, random slopes for participants will be included into the modell (see analysis plan).
registration_responses.q20: If the model for analysing the reaction times does not meet the condition of homoscedasticity and normal distribution of residuals, the reaction times will be transformed into log-reaction times.
registration_responses.q21: The alphal-evel is set to .01. Based on the estimates for reaction times of the prestudy, an R2m of  .07and an R2c of .29  is expected.
registration_responses.q22: As explained in the data collection procedures, participants will be excluded that do not speak German as their L1, are bilingual, lived in Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg,  Rhineland Palatinate or Saarland before their 12th year of life or have dyslexia. Additionally, the response bevaviour of the participants will be evaluated and data exclusion will be based on this evaluation. In addition, participants whose reaction time is over 3 sd above the mean of reaction times for a level of the category prototypicality (e.g. transitive), will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23: Incomplete data sets of participants will not be included into the study. If meta data (except for  the indication of L1, indication of places where participants lived until the 12th year of life and the indication of dyslexia) is missing, particpiants will still be included into the study.
registration_responses.q24:
The exploratory analysis will include "reiten" which is excluded from the confirmatory analysis. The same models will be tested that have been described in "statistical models". 

Additionally to these models, a model is used including "item" as fixed effect in order to measure the influence of the test items on reaction times (see prestudy_prototypicality.R for the code). Item and transitivity will be fixed effects in the model that may interact. Participants are included as random effect. 

RT ~ transitivity*item + (1+transitivity|participant)

For the generalized mixed linear model on response behaviour, random effects had to be dropped completely in the prestudy (see prestudy_prototypicality.R) not only for analysing "fahren" and "fliegen" but also when analysing all items. Hence, a conditional inference tree and a random forest were calculated additionally for the response behaviour including all items. The same method will be used for the main study if necessary.

Within the tree and the forest, transitivity as well as the test item will be included as factors:

Auxiliar ~ Transitivy + Item

Item is included because the data of the prestudy indicates that "reiten" elicits different response patterns than the other verbs. The code for the prestudy also includes a tree without item as factor. For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_prototypicality.R.

The described models are included into the exploratory analysis and not into the confirmatory analysis because the interaction of item and transitivity is not the main interest of the study, but the influence of transitivity (and hence prototypicality) on reaction times and on the response behaviour.
registration_responses.q25:
Literature

Gillmann, Melitta (2016). Perfektkonstruktionen mit "haben" und "sein": Eine Korpusuntersuchung im Althochdeutschen, Altsächsischen und Neuhochdeutschen. Boston: de Gruyter.

Roehm, Dietmar; Sorace, Antonella; Bornkessel-Schlesewsky, Ina (2013). Processing flexible form-to-meaning mappings: Evidence for enriched compoflitersition as opposed to indeterminacy. In: Language and Cognitive Processes 28.8, 1244–1274.

RStudio Team (2015). RStudio: Integrated Development for R. RStudio, Inc., Boston. http://www.rstudio.com/.

registration_responses.q8.question:
A within subject design is used with two factors (transitivity and inflection) with four (transitive, ambiguous I, ambiguous II, intransitive) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Within the levels of transitivity, three test words are used. Only two will be used in the confirmatory analysis, see statistical models. All three test words will be used in the exploratory analysis. The participants can choose between the auxiliaries "hat" and "ist" for each test word. The answer (hat/ist) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
Nouns belonging to the so-called weak declension class in German are used within filler sentences. Here, participants have to choose between weak and strong genitive endings. These items are used as test items in a study on the influence of schemata on variation. Additionally, filler sentences with similar content as the test sentences are used. The whole study design distracts participants form the research interest, as participants always have to choose between two forms. Within the study, participants have to detect grammatical, semantic and orthographic deviations. 
To test the design, forms containing errors in gender marking (der.Mask Kurier.Mask 'courier'/*die.Fem Lieferant.Mask 'delivery man') and in orthography (Schule/*Schuhle ‘school’) are included into the study as well as variants (Fahrrad fahren/fahrradfahren ‘to ride a bike’; fehlerlos/fehlerfrei ‘without mistakes’). For the two errors, a fast and clearly distributed response behaviour is expected. For the two variants, slow reaction times and an inconsistent response behaviour are hypothesised. Hence, the items allow to test, whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The design will only be tested if the test items show no differences in reaction times. 

If the design needs to be tested, the following mixed linear model will be used: RT ~ Variante + (1+Variante|participant)+(1|item). Variante is the manipulated variable that contains two levels: Variante (fehlerlos/fehlerfrei; Fahrradfahren, Fahrrad fahren) and kVariante (Schule/*Schuhle; der Kurier/*die Lieferant). For the response behaviour, a generalized mixed linear model will be used: preferred form ~ Variante + (1+Variante|participant)+(1|item).

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5, (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study. 

Test items
The verbs "fahren" ‘to drive’, "reiten" ‘to ride’ and "fliegen" ‘to fly’ are used as test items as they can be used with different degrees of transitivity. They are used in the following sentences:

Transitive (object that is used as patient)

Er sah, wie die Mutter die Kinder zur Schule gefahren hat/*ist.
He saw that the mother drove the children to the school.

Ich nehme an, dass der Pilot die Passagiere zum nächstgelegenen Flughafen geflogen hat/*ist.
I guess that the pilot flew the passengers to the closest airport.

Ich gehe davon aus, dass das Mädchen das Pferd zur Koppel geritten hat/*ist.
I guess that the girl rode the horse to the paddock.

Ambiguous I (object ambiguous between patient and instrument)

Er erzählte mir, dass seine Tante eine Zeit lang ein Cabrio gefahren hat/ist.
He told me that his aunt drove a convertible for some time.

Ich kann kaum glauben, dass meine Schwester neulich einen Helikopter geflogen hat/ist.
I cannot believe that my sister flew a helicopter the other day.

Mir wurde erzählt, dass mein Onkel früher ein schwarzes Pferd geritten hat/ist.
I was told that my uncle rode a black horse in the past.

Ambiguous II (ambiguous between object and adverbial)

In den Nachrichten sagten sie, dass der neue Fahrer die Strecke in Rekordzeit gefahren ist/hat.
They said in the news that the new driver drove the circuit in record time.

In der Zeitung stand, dass der Pilot die Distanz in Bestzeit geflogen ist/hat.
I read in the newspapers that the pilot flew the distance in minimum time.

Im Radio hieß es, dass der Reiter den Parcours fehlerlos geritten ist/hat.
They said in the radio that the jockey rode the course without any mistakes.

Intransitive (no object)

Ich ging davon aus, dass die Oma am Sonntag zur Kur gefahren ist/*hat.
I thought that grandmother drove to the clinic on Sunday.

Ich wusste nicht, dass mein Bruder am Mittwoch in die USA geflogen ist/*hat.
I did not know that my brother flew to the US on Wednesday.

Meine Oma erzählte, dass sie in den Siebzigern regelmäßig durch den Schwarzwald geritten ist/*hat.
My grandmother told me that she was frequently horseback riding through the black forest in the seventies.

The test sentences were tested for their semantic plausibility. Except for one sentence, all test sentences were rated plausible (at least 3 on a scale from 1 (not plausible) to 5 (plausible), see the attached file (test sentences.csv) for details). Only the test sentence "Mir wurde erzählt, dass mein Onkel früher ein schwarzes Pferd geritten hat" had to be changed slightly. Originally, "während des Studiums" ('during his studies‘) was used instead of "früher" (‘in the past’). As the rated plausibility of this sentence was rather low (2,7), "während des Studiums" was changed to "früher" so that the test sentence is more similar to the other test sentences containing "reiten" as test verb. Another slight change had to be made in the sentence containing "Parcours" ('course'): within the semantic pausibility test, the form "Parkour" was used which is normally not used in the context of horse back riding.

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over the stimuli and the filler items. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: 
unique coding for each stimulus 	

Verwendung: 
coding for the test auxiliaries, levels: trans,ambigI,ambigII, intrans
coding for the items testing the design, levels: nVariante (no variant), Variante (variant)
coding for the test nouns, levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach (not relevant for this study)

Item: 
naming the test items in their base form (main verbs; masculine nouns (not relevant for this study))

Evaluation: 
"ev" in the column highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the items have been answered wrong, the participant will be excluded)	

akzeptierteForm: 
stating which of the forms is expected to be accepted (only for test items), levels: ist/hat/both; n/s/both (not relevant for this study)

Element_richtig: stating the correct element 

Element_Alternative: stating the alternative

Block: block in which the item is presented	

PositionimBlock: position within the block

ElementA: stating ElementA (presented at the left)

ElementA_präf: stating whether ElementA is preferred over ElementB; levels: j (yes), n (no)

ElementB: stating ElementB (presented at the right)

ElementB_präf: stating whether ElementB is preferred over ElementA;  levels: j (yes), n (no)

correctKey: correct response key (based on ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf); levels: f (Element A preferred); j (Element B preferred)

Further explanation for "correctKey": For items which are considered variants, "correctKey" was not specified. For these items, ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf are both coded with j. Note that some filler items (like "dass/das"; "seid/seit") are not variants but are often confused so that both forms were coded as acceptable.

Further explanation to "Element_richtig" and "Element_Alternative": These columns are not used for the analysis of the data. Their only purpose is to help the user spot the correct and alternative forms in the design more easily. For items that are considered variants, Element_richtig and Element_Alternative are also stated.  The variants were assigned randomly to Element_richtig and Element_Alterantive, as both forms are equally likely. They are only used in these columns so that the test sentences can be read completely. In the columns relevant for analysis (ElementA_präf/ElementB_präf, correctKey), these items are coded as variants (ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf are coded with j; correctKey is not specified).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students.  If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. In order to avoid regional variation influencing the data, the study will not be distributed in the counties Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg, Rhineland Palatinate and Saarland. In this counties, position verbs are used with "sein" instead of "haben" (Scherr 2019).  This could have an effect on the reaction times and the response behaviour with respect to the test verbs. Participants who indicate one of the stated counties as the county they grew up in will be excluded from the sample.
The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1, indicate that they grew up in a county stated above or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task.This evaluation will be based on 132 filler items. For these items, people should not vary in their answers. The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer 13 items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category transitivity (e.g., intransitive/ambiguousI) are excluded from the sample.

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/maze.
registration_responses.q16.question: The transitivity of the sentences is manipulated in which the test words are used. This categorial variable consists of four levels: transitive, ambiguousI, ambiguousII and intransitive (see study design for an explanation of the levels). Additionally, the auxiliar is manipulated. The levels of this nominal variable are "hat" and "ist".
registration_responses.q17.question:
The outcome variables will be the response behaviour (hat/ist) as well as reaction times to sentences with different degrees of transitivity (see manipulated variables). This is measured by letting the participants choose between the auxiliar "hat" and "ist" at the end of the sentence. The participants are asked to choose the option that fits best to the parts of the sentence that they have read so far. ("Wählen Sie die Möglichkeit, die für Sie am besten zu dem bisher gelesenen Satz passt." 'Choose the option that fits best into the parts of the sentence that you have read so far').  Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 

Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data is used to exclude participants from the study (see data collection procedures) and not included into the confirmatory analysis.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019, RStudio Team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.
For the confirmatiory analysis, only "fahren" and "fliegen" will be included into the model. "reiten" elicited a  different response behaviour and different reaction time patterns in the prestudy (see the data (data_prestudy_prototypicality.csv) and the code (prestudy_prototypicality.R) analysing the data of the prestudy). Because of this, "reiten" will only be included into the exploratory analysis.

Reaction times

To evaluate the influence of transitivity on reaction times, a mixed linear model will be conducted. The degree of transitivity (transitive, ambiguous I, ambiguous II, intransitive) is included as fixed effect. Test items and participants are included as random effects. The independent variable is transitivity. The reaction times are the dependent variable.

RT~transitivity +(1+transitivy|item)+(1+transitivy|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes are dropped and only random intercepts are included into the model.

Preference for "haben" or "sein"

To evaluate differences in the preference for "haben" and "sein", a logistic mixed linear model is used. Transitivity (transitive, ambiguous I, ambiguous II, intransitive) is included as fixed effect. Test items and participants are included as random effects. The independent variable is transitivity. The preference for "haben" or "sein" is the dependent variable.

Preference ~ transitivity + (1+transitivity|item)+(1+transitivity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes are dropped and only random intercepts are included into the model.

In the prestudy, convergence issues were reported for the statistical model so that the random effects had to be dropped completely (see prestudy_prototypicality.R). Therefore, a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest was calculated additionally. This will also be carried out in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, transitivity will be included as factor:

Auxiliar ~ Transitivy 

For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_prototypicality.R.

attributes.title: Effects of schemata on variation (sentence maze)

q1.value: Examining effects of schemata and frequency on masculine nouns in German using a sentence maze task

q3.value:
The influence of schemata on the inflection of masculine nouns in German has been well examined in corpora (Köpcke 1995, 2000a, 2000b, 2005, Schäfer 2016). Prototypically, polysyllabic nouns stressed on the penultimate syllable ending with schwa and referring to human beings belong to the so-called weak declension class. Variation can be observed if a noun diverges from the formal (polysyllabic, stress on the penultimate syllable, schwa) or semantic (referring to human beings) features: These nouns vary between weak and strong forms. The strong declension class is the type frequent class concerning masculine nouns. 
Additionally to the schema, token frequency influences whether a noun that is part of the type infrequent weak declension will stay in this class or chance to the type frequent class: Nouns with high token frequency show stable declension, nouns with low token frequency tend to vary between strong and weak forms (Schäfer 2016).

To my knowledge, psycholinguistic studies concerning this topic are missing so far. Psycholinguistic studies on declension in German examine, e.g., the processing of regular and irregular plural forms (Penke and Krause 2002; Sonnenstuhl and Huth 2002) but do not examine effects of schemata. An exception to this is Schmitt (2019). Here, effects of schemata are examined with the help of a self-paced reading task using pseudo nouns. Schmitt (2019) could not measure differences between reading times for weak and strong genitive endings of the pseudo noun "Schettose" which perfectly matches the schema of the weak masculine class and thus should facilitate the processing of weak endings. An effect of schemata is therefore not observable in reading times. However, participants had a clear preference for the weak ending in the production task within the study. Hence, there seems to be conflicting evidence for effects of schemata. 

This study examines effects of schema with the help of a sentence maze task. Within a sentence maze, participants are ask to build a sentence bit by bit. For each chunk of a sentence, participants choose between two options. In this task, participants choose between strong and weak genitive forms of real existing nouns (des Kollegen/des Kolleges 'the colleague.GEN'). The nouns belong to the schema to different extents: Nouns that match the schema completely are compared to nouns in the periphery of the schema. Additionally, nouns that are similar to the nouns in the periphery of the schema but do not belong to the weak declension class are included into the study. The animacy of the test nouns is held constant as all test nouns refer to human beings. The test nouns have a relative token frequency of max. 2 hits per million token.

q4.value:
1. reaction times

Reaction times are fast for nouns in the periphery, but slow for nouns that prototypically match the schema and for nouns that are part of the strong declension class.This hypothesis is based on the results of a prestudy (see https://osf.io/eahgf for the preregistration of the prestudy, data_prestudy_schema_sentence.csv for the data and prestudy_schema_sentence.R for the code analysing the data). The difference between nouns in the periphery and the other test nouns is likely due to token frequency. The influence of token frequency was tried to be controlled (see study design), however, slight differences between the nouns could not be avoided. 
Originally, it was hypothesised that the reaction times are fast for nouns that prototypically match the schema or do not belong to the weak declension class. In contrast, they were expected to be slow for nouns that are in the periphery of the schema. 

If faster reaction times for the nouns in the periphery of the schema can be observed in the main study, this can be interpreted as an indicator for token frequencies having an higher impact on reaction times than schemata (see also Exploratory Analysis testing the influene of token frequency). If the opposite is true, the slightly differing token frequencies of the test nouns do not seem to have influenced the reaction times but differences in schematicity: As two forms are theoretically possible for nouns in the periphery of the schema, the reaction times are higher than for nouns where only one entrenchend form exists.

2. preference in response behaviour

The choice between strong (-s) and weak (-n) endings depends on the form of the nouns: If the noun is compliant with the schema, -n is preferred. Nouns that do not belong to the weak declension class will show a preference for -s. Based on the prestudy, a preference for -n is hypothesised for the nouns in the periphery. As the participants see the new and less frequent ending next to the old and more frequent ending, they choose the more familiar and thus more frequent one. Originally, it was hypothesised that participants will vary between choosing -n and -s with respect to nouns  in the periphery of the schema.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
A within subject design is used with two factors (schematicity and inflection) with three levels (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Per level of schematicity, three test words are used. The participants can choose between the weak (-n) and the strong genitive form (-s) for the test words. The answer (-n/-s) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. Filler sentences are used with different degrees of transitivity where participants need to choose the auxiliary (ist/hat). These items are used as test items for a study on effects of prototypicality on variation. Additionally, filler sentences with similar content as the test sentences are used. The whole study design distracts participants from the research interest, as participants always have to choose between two forms. Within the study, participants have to detect grammatical, semantic and orthographic deviations. 

To test the design, forms containing errors in gender marking (der.Mask Kurier.Mask 'courier'/*die.Fem Lieferant.Mask 'delivery man')  and in orthography (Schule/*Schuhle ‘school’) are included into the study as well as variants (Fahrrad fahren/fahrradfahren ‘to ride a bike’; fehlerlos/fehlerfrei ‘without mistakes’).  For the two errors, a fast and clearly distributed response behaviour is expected. For the two variants, slow reaction times and an inconsistent response behaviour are hypothesised. Hence, the items allow to test, whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The design will only be tested if the test items show no differences in reaction times. 

If the design needs to be tested, the following mixed linear model will be used: RT ~ Variante + (1+Variante|participant)+(1|item). Variante is the manipulated variable that contains two levels: Variante (fehlerlos/fehlerfrei; Fahrradfahren, Fahrrad fahren) and kVariante (Schule/*Schuhle; der Kurier/*die Lieferant). For the response behaviour, a generalized mixed linear model will be used: preferred form ~ Variante + (1+Variante|participant)+(1|item).

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5, (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study. 

Test items

Prototype of the schema: Kollege ‘colleague’, Neffe ‘nephew‘, Schütze ‘marksman‘

Periphery of the schema: Graf ‘count’, Held ‘hero’, Zar ‘tsar’

Not belonging to the weak declension class: Dieb ‘thief’, Freund ‘friend’, Vogt  ‘reeve’

In order to avoid frequency effects, nouns are used that have a frequency of up to two hits per million tokens in 2018. The reported frequencies are based on the word frequencies provided by the Digital Dictionary of the German Language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). However, there are slight differences in frequency within the test words. Two nouns that prototypically match the schema have a relative frequency of 0.4 ("des Schützen") and 0.6 ("des Kollegen") hits per million tokens but "des Neffen" is less frequent (0.05 hits per million tokens). The words that are in the periphery of the schema have a frequency of 0.4 to 0.5 hits per million tokens. One of the words not belonging to the weak class is similar frequent ("des Freundes", 0.3 hits per million tokens), but the other two are less frequent (up to 0.04 hits per million tokens). Hence, the nouns not belonging to the weak declension class tend to be less frequent than the other test words. However, "des Neffen", belonging to prototype of the schema, is comparable infrequent. All in all, the token frequencies of the test words are on a comparable level. Nonetheless, they seem to have an influence on reaction times (see Hypotheses and Exploratory Analysis). See the attachment (test nouns.csv) for an overview over the test words and their relative frequencies.
 
The frequency of the forms is estimated using the word frequencies provided by the Digital Dictionary of the German Language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). Test nouns are searched in the genitive singular (with the more frequently used ending). In order to avoid false positives, determiners are used in the search (e.g. @des @Kollegen ‘the colleague’).

The test words are used in the following sentences:

Ich nehme an, dass die Arbeit meines Kollegen/*Kolleges wertgeschätzt wird.
I guess that the work of my colleague is acknowledged.

Ich habe gesehen, wie der Pfeil des Schützen/*Schützes ins Schwarze traf.
I saw that the shooter’s arrow hit the mark.

Mein Freund war nicht da, weil er zum Geburtstag seines Neffen/*Neffes gegangen ist.
My friend was not there because he went to his nephew’s birthday.

Mein Neffe mag Superman nicht, weil ihm der Anzug des Helden/Helds nicht gefällt.
My nephew does not like superman because he does not like the hero’s suit. 

Sie konnte nicht fassen, dass das Anwesen des Grafen/Grafs so groß ist wie ein Schloss.
She could not believe that the count’s estate is as big as a castle.

Ihm war nicht bewusst, dass die Macht des Zaren/Zars einmal derart groß gewesen ist.
He did not know that the power of the tsar had once been so great. 

Er fährt nochmal zurück, weil er die Jacke seines Freundes/*Freunden aus Versehen eingesteckt hat und dieser sie auf der Arbeit benötigt.
He drives back again because he accidentally took the jacket of his friend and his friend needs the jacket at work.

Der Krimi-Fan ahnt schon früh, dass der Plan des Diebes/*Dieben zu simpel ist und nicht klappt.
The fan of thrillers will know early on that the thief’s plan is too simple and will not work.

Er macht einen Ausflug, um die Burg des Vogts/*Vogten zu betrachten.
He arranged an excursion so that he could see the reeve’s fort. 

The sentences were tested for their semantic plausibility. All test items were rated plausible: at least 3 on a scale from 1 (not plausible) to 5 (plausible), see the attachment (test sentences.csv) for details. Only one sentence was slightly modified after the semantic plausibility test. Originally, instead of "wertgeschätzt" "gewertschätzt" was used.

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over the stimuli and the filler items. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: 
unique coding for each stimulus 	

Verwendung: 
coding for the test nouns, levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach
coding for the items testing the design, levels: nVariante (no variant), Variante (variant)
coding for the test auxiliaries, levels: trans,ambigI,ambigII, intrans  (not relevant for this study) 

Item: 
naming the test items in their base form (test nouns; main verbs (not relevant for this study))

Evaluation: 
"ev" highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the items have been answered wrong, participant will be excluded)	

akzeptierteForm: 
stating which of the forms is expected to be accepted (only for test items), levels: n/s/both; ist/hat/both (not relevant for this study)

Element_richtig: 
stating the correct element 

Element_Alternative: 
stating the alternative

Block: 
block in which the item is presented	

PositionimBlock: 
position within the block

ElementA: 
stating ElementA (presented at the left)

ElementA_präf: 
stating whether ElementA is preferred over ElementB; levels: j (yes), n (no)

ElementB: 
stating ElementB (presented at the right)

ElementB_präf: 
stating whether ElementB is preferred over ElementA;  levels: j (yes), n (no)

correctKey: 
correct response key (based on ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf); levels: f (Element A preferred); j (Element B preferred)

Further explanation for "correctKey": For items which are considered variants, "correctKey" was not specified. For these items "ElementA_präf" and "ElementB_präf" are both coded with j. Note that some filler items (like "dass/das"; "seid/seit") are not variants but are often confused so that both forms were coded as acceptable.

Further explanation to "Element_richtig" and "Element_Alternative": These columns are not used for the analysis of the data. Their only purpose is to help the user to spot the correct and alternative forms in the design more easily. For items that are considered variants, "Element_richtig" and "Element_Alternative" are also stated. The variants were assigned randomly to "Element_richtig" and "Element_Alterantive", as both forms are equally likely to be accepted. They are only used in these columns so that the test sentences can be read completely. In the relevant columns (ElementA_präf/ElementB_präf, correctKey), these items are coded as variants (ElementA_präf and ElementB_präf are coded with j; correctKey is not specified).

q9.value: The test items are organized in four blocks. In each block, two to three test nouns with different degrees of schematicity are used. Additionally, three to four filler sentences are included in each block. The order of the test sentences within the blocks is constant. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students. If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. As the filler sentences within this study are used as test sentences in a study on auxiliar selection in German, the study will not be distributed in the counties Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg, Rhineland Palatinate and Saarland, in order to avoid regional variation influencing the results of this study. This is not important for the present study, as the variation between weak and strong declension is not regionally distributed. Hence, participants will not be excluded from this study if they indicate that they grew up in one of the counties stated above.
The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1 or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task.This evaluation will be based on 132 filler items. For these items, people should not vary in their answers. The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer 13 items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema/periphery) are excluded from the sample.

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/maze.

q13.value:
A sample size of 125 participants is targeted. To reach this number, 170 participants will be recruited. In the prestudy, five of 32 participants (16 %)  had to be excluded due to missing meta data, response behaviour indicating a lack of concentration and reaction times above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema, periphery).  Hence, 25 % more data are collected in order to ensure that the targeted sample size of 125 is reached.

See https://osf.io/eahgf the preregistration of the prestudy. Deviating from the preregistration of the prestudy, participants were exluded if 10 % of the items evaluating the concentration of the participants were answered incorrectly. Additionally, participants were excluded whose reaction times were 3 sd above the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema).

q14.value:
The sample size is set to 125 participants based on a power analysis for the reaction times: 125 participants are required to reach a power of 0.8 with an alpha level of 0.01 for the estimate -0.2 for the level "periphery" of the category "schematicity" in comparions to the level "schema". The estimate is based on the results of a mixed linear model analysing the data of the prestudy. The data of the prestudy (data_prestudy_schema_sentence.csv) as well as the code used for analysing the data (prestudy_schema_sentence.R) is attached.  See https://osf.io/eahgf for the preregistered analysis plan of the prestudy. The code for the data simulation (power analysis_schema_sentence.R) calculating the power based on the estimates of the prestudy is attached as well. The simulation was repeated 10000 times, a file with 10000 repitions of the simulation is attached (sims_schema_sent.csv). See section "statistical models" for the attached files. The code for the data simulation is based on a tutorial for power analyses with R by DeBruine and Barr (preprint).
Note that the power analysis is based on a model that only uses random intercepts, as the model had convergence issues when random slopes were used. For the main study, random slopes for participants will be included into the modell (see analysis plan).

question.value: Schematicity is the manipulated variable as test words are chosen that match the schema to different degrees. The three levels of this categorial variable are prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema and not belonging to the weak declension class (see study design for further explanation of the levels). The forms of the test words are manipulated as well. The nominal variable has the levels weak and strong.

The outcome variables are the response behaviour (s-ending/n-ending) as well as reaction times to weak and strong forms of nouns belonging to the weak declension class to different degrees. The response is elicited by letting participants choose between the weak and the strong genitive ending of the test words within a sentence. The participants' task is to choose the option that fits best to the parts of the sentence they have read so far ("Wählen Sie die Möglichkeit, die für Sie am besten zu dem bisher gelesenen Satz passt." 'Choose the option that fits best into the parts of the sentence that you have read so far').
 
Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data is used to exclude participants from the study. It will not be used for confirmatory analysis.

For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019, RStudio Team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.

Reaction times

To evaluate the influence of schematicity on reaction times, a mixed linear model will be conducted. The degree of schematicity (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) is included as fixed effect. Item and participant are included as random effects. Item will only be included with random intercepts as items vary across categories. The independent variable is the degree of schematicity. Reaction times are the dependent variable.

Reaction time ~ schematicity + (1|item)+ (1+schematicity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes are dropped and only random intercepts are included into the model.

Preference for weak and strong endings

To evaluate differences in the preference for weak or strong endings, a logistic mixed linear model is used. The degree of schematicity (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) is included as fixed effect. Item and participant are included as random effects. Items will only be included with random intercepts as they vary across categories. The independent variable is the schematicity. The preference for the weak or strong ending is the dependent variable.

Preference ~ schematicity+ (1|item)+ (1+schematicity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes are dropped and only random intercepts are included into the model.

In the prestudy, convergence issues were reported for the statistical model so that random effects had to be dropped completely (see prestudy_schema_sentence.R). Therefore, a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest were calculated additionally. This will also be done in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, schematicity will be included as factor:

Preference ~ Schema 

For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_schema_sentence.R.

q20.value: If the model for analysing the reaction times does not meet the condition of homoscedasticity and normal distribution of residuals, the reaction times will be transformed into log-reaction times.

q21.value: The alpha-level is set to 0.01. Based on the estimates for reaction times of the prestudy, an R2m of .08 and an R2c of .42 is expected.

q22.value: As explained in the data collection procedures, participants will be excluded that do not speak German as their L1, are bilingual or have dyslexia. Additionally, the response bevaviour of the participants will be evaluated and data exclusion will be based on this evaluation. In addition, participants whose reaction time is over 3 sd above the mean of reaction times for a level of the category schematicity (e.g. periphery), will be excluded.

q23.value: Incomplete data sets of participants will not be included into the study. If meta data (except for  the indication of L1 and dyslexia) is missing, particpiants will still be included into the study.

q24.value:
In order to evaluate the hypothesised influence of frequency, the test items will be assigned frequency levels (frequent, middle frequent, infrequent) based on their relative frequency (see prestudy_schema_sentence.R) so that each level includes three items. Frequency will be included into a mixed linear model as fixed factor with participant and item as random effects. For participants, random intercepts and random slopes will be included. For items, only random intercepts will be used as items vary across categories.

RT ~ Frequency + (1+Frequency |participant)+ (1|item)

The estimates of this model will be compared to the estimates of the model analysing the influence of schematicity.
A similar analysis (without random slopes for participants) was already calculated within the prestudy indicating that frequency has comparable estimates as schematicity (see prestudy_schema_sentence.R for the code).

registration_responses.q1: Examining effects of schemata and frequency on masculine nouns in German using a sentence maze task
registration_responses.q3:
The influence of schemata on the inflection of masculine nouns in German has been well examined in corpora (Köpcke 1995, 2000a, 2000b, 2005, Schäfer 2016). Prototypically, polysyllabic nouns stressed on the penultimate syllable ending with schwa and referring to human beings belong to the so-called weak declension class. Variation can be observed if a noun diverges from the formal (polysyllabic, stress on the penultimate syllable, schwa) or semantic (referring to human beings) features: These nouns vary between weak and strong forms. The strong declension class is the type frequent class concerning masculine nouns. 
Additionally to the schema, token frequency influences whether a noun that is part of the type infrequent weak declension will stay in this class or chance to the type frequent class: Nouns with high token frequency show stable declension, nouns with low token frequency tend to vary between strong and weak forms (Schäfer 2016).

To my knowledge, psycholinguistic studies concerning this topic are missing so far. Psycholinguistic studies on declension in German examine, e.g., the processing of regular and irregular plural forms (Penke and Krause 2002; Sonnenstuhl and Huth 2002) but do not examine effects of schemata. An exception to this is Schmitt (2019). Here, effects of schemata are examined with the help of a self-paced reading task using pseudo nouns. Schmitt (2019) could not measure differences between reading times for weak and strong genitive endings of the pseudo noun "Schettose" which perfectly matches the schema of the weak masculine class and thus should facilitate the processing of weak endings. An effect of schemata is therefore not observable in reading times. However, participants had a clear preference for the weak ending in the production task within the study. Hence, there seems to be conflicting evidence for effects of schemata. 

This study examines effects of schema with the help of a sentence maze task. Within a sentence maze, participants are ask to build a sentence bit by bit. For each chunk of a sentence, participants choose between two options. In this task, participants choose between strong and weak genitive forms of real existing nouns (des Kollegen/des Kolleges 'the colleague.GEN'). The nouns belong to the schema to different extents: Nouns that match the schema completely are compared to nouns in the periphery of the schema. Additionally, nouns that are similar to the nouns in the periphery of the schema but do not belong to the weak declension class are included into the study. The animacy of the test nouns is held constant as all test nouns refer to human beings. The test nouns have a relative token frequency of max. 2 hits per million token.
registration_responses.q4:
1. reaction times

Reaction times are fast for nouns in the periphery, but slow for nouns that prototypically match the schema and for nouns that are part of the strong declension class.This hypothesis is based on the results of a prestudy (see https://osf.io/eahgf for the preregistration of the prestudy, data_prestudy_schema_sentence.csv for the data and prestudy_schema_sentence.R for the code analysing the data). The difference between nouns in the periphery and the other test nouns is likely due to token frequency. The influence of token frequency was tried to be controlled (see study design), however, slight differences between the nouns could not be avoided. 
Originally, it was hypothesised that the reaction times are fast for nouns that prototypically match the schema or do not belong to the weak declension class. In contrast, they were expected to be slow for nouns that are in the periphery of the schema. 

If faster reaction times for the nouns in the periphery of the schema can be observed in the main study, this can be interpreted as an indicator for token frequencies having an higher impact on reaction times than schemata (see also Exploratory Analysis testing the influene of token frequency). If the opposite is true, the slightly differing token frequencies of the test nouns do not seem to have influenced the reaction times but differences in schematicity: As two forms are theoretically possible for nouns in the periphery of the schema, the reaction times are higher than for nouns where only one entrenchend form exists.

2. preference in response behaviour

The choice between strong (-s) and weak (-n) endings depends on the form of the nouns: If the noun is compliant with the schema, -n is preferred. Nouns that do not belong to the weak declension class will show a preference for -s. Based on the prestudy, a preference for -n is hypothesised for the nouns in the periphery. As the participants see the new and less frequent ending next to the old and more frequent ending, they choose the more familiar and thus more frequent one. Originally, it was hypothesised that participants will vary between choosing -n and -s with respect to nouns  in the periphery of the schema.
